title: 109_hr3749
content:
The "Gulf State Community Renewal Commission Act" establishes the Gulf State Community Renewal Commission to address the colossal devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina and the national redevelopment obligation it poses. The Commission will utilize the expertise of professionals in city and regional planning, architecture, home building, and finance. The Gulf State Community Renewal Commission aims to examine, evaluate, and report on the rebuilding of communities in urban and rural areas affected by Hurricane Katrina. It also identifies actions, professions, and resources necessary for rebuilding, creating models and plans that address various needs such as transportation, economic development, housing, agriculture, environment, and disaster mitigation. The Gulf State Community Renewal Commission focuses on rebuilding communities affected by Hurricane Katrina in urban and rural areas. It also includes other relevant sectors determined by the Commission. The Gulf State Community Renewal Commission determines the composition of the commission. The Gulf State Community Renewal Commission is composed of 21 members appointed by the President, including experts in city planning, historians, homebuilders, mortgage finance, and small business issues. 14 members are from Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana, with 7 members from other states. The Gulf State Community Renewal Commission consists of 21 members appointed by the President, including experts in various fields. All members must be appointed by October 30, 2005. The Commission will have a chairperson and two vice chairpersons, with one resident from each State holding a position. The Commission will meet promptly after all members are appointed. A quorum of 11 members is required for meetings, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Gulf State Community Renewal Commission, consisting of 21 members appointed by the President, is tasked with conducting hearings, examinations, and studies to fulfill its purposes. It must submit reports to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations on rebuilding neighborhoods and communities affected by Hurricane Katrina. The Commission also has the power to carry out its duties effectively. The Gulf State Community Renewal Commission has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, and enter into contracts to fulfill its duties under the Act. It can also obtain information from federal agencies and receive assistance from the General Services Administration. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other departments and agencies of the United States can also offer services, funds, facilities, staff, and support as authorized by law. The Commission can use the United States mails and subcommittees, members, or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can utilize administrative support from the General Services Administration on a reimbursable basis. Other US departments and agencies can provide services, funds, facilities, staff, and support as authorized by law. The Commission can also use the United States mails and authorize actions by subcommittees, members, or agents. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, who can appoint additional staff as needed. The Director and staff may be appointed without following certain civil service laws, with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can appoint experts and consultants at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their rights and privileges. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES.

Each Commission member may be compensated at a daily rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties, following government service expense guidelines.

SEC. 10. REPORTS; TERMINATION. The Commission is required to submit an initial report within 90 days of its first meeting, and incremental reports at 12 and 24 months after the initial report. The Commission will terminate 60 days after the second incremental report is submitted. During this period, they may conclude activities and provide testimony to Congress. Authorization of appropriations for the Commission under this Act is set at $7,500,000, with funds remaining available until expended.
